questions.text: A 48 year old male presented to the casualty with a history of high-grade fever, cough, and diarrhea for 5 days. On examination pulse is 120 bpm, BP-70/40 mmHg, RR-22 cpm, and Spo2 88% on room air. He is transferred to ICU and started on oxygen support, inotropic support, and empirical antibiotics are started after drawing blood for culture. His initial ABG and electrolyte report are shown below.LFT and RFT are within normal limits. Identify the TRUE statement among the given options. pH- 7.2 PCO2-26 pO2- 93mmHg HCO3- 12mmHg Lactate-4.9 mmol/l Na/K/Cl – 139/3.6/110

options.label: A
options.text: This is a case of Type B lactic acidosis

options.label: B
options.text: There is presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis + normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

options.label: C
options.text: Pyroglutamic acidemia occurs in patients taking aspirin.

options.label: D
options.text: L-lactic acidosis is due to formation of L-lactate by gut bacteria

questions.correct_answer: B. There is presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis + normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis + normal anion gap metabolic acidosis Gap metabolic acidosis In cases of high-AG metabolic acidosis, it is valuable to compare a) the decline in HCO3 i.e ΔHCO3 = 25 – patient’s HCO3 with b) the increase in the AG i.e ΔAG = patient’s AG – 10 Delta ratio (ΔAG / ΔHCO3) is a formula that can be used to assess elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis and to evaluate whether a mixed acid–base disorder metabolic acidosis ) is present. Here the delta ratio is 17-10 / 25-12 = 7 / 13 = 0.53 If the delta ratio is somewhere between 0.4 and 1, then it is usually due to a combination of high anion gap metabolic acidosis and normal anion gap acidosis The patient here due to diarrhea may have developed a normal anion gap acidosis, but became progressively dehydrated and developed lactic acidosis from shock and eventually developed a high anion gap metabolic acidosis . (i.e. now a mixed acid-base disorder )

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: L- lactic acidosis due to an increase in plasma L-lactate secondary to poor tissue perfusion ( type A ) Option C: Pyroglutamic acidemia may occur in critically ill patients who are receiving acetaminophen, which causes depletion of glutathione and accumulation of 5-polyproline. Option D: D- Lactic acid acidosis is due to the formation of d-lactate by gut bacteria in association with jejunoileal bypass, short bowel syndrome, or intestinal obstruction

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with chronic liver disease is admitted to a medical ICU with an episode of hematemesis. His ABG is suggestive of metabolic acidosis. His serum albumin is 2.5 g/dl.Calculate the corrected anion gap in this patient. Na+-138 meq/l K+-3.8meq/l Ca-9.5mg/dl Cl- -106 meq/l pH-7.3 PCo2-30mmHg Po2-95mmHg HCO3-14 meq/l
questions.explanation:
Solution:

23 meq/l The Anion gap (AG) is calculated as AG = Na – (Cl + HCO3). The normal value for the AG is 6 to 12 mmol/L (an average of ∼10 mmol/L). If hypoalbuminemia is present, the value for the AG must be corrected . For each 1 g/ dL of serum albumin falling below the normal value (4.5 g/dL), 5 mmol/L should be added to the reported (uncorrected) AG. In this patient, the uncorrected AG is 18 mmol/L (138 - (106 + 14)) With serum albumin of 2.5 g/dL (The value is 2 g/dL below the normal value), so we add 5 mmol/L (2.5 X 2) to the uncorrected AG, so the corrected AG is 23 mmol/L (5 + 18)

Highyeild:

AG may increase with an increase in anionic albumin. A decrease in the AG can be due to a reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration ( nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption )

Extraedge:

The unmeasured anions normally present in plasma include anionic proteins (albumin), phosphate, sulfate, and organic anions. An increase in the AG is most often due to an increase in unmeasured anions and, less commonly, may be due to a decrease in unmeasured cations ( calcium, magnesium, potassium)

questions.text: A 42-year-old male is brought to the emergency with salicylate poisoning. ABG done is suggestive of metabolic acidosis + respiratory alkalosis. Which of the following statements are true regarding his treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Gastric lavage with NaHCO3 should be done immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Alkalinization of urine to maintain urine ph <7.5

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperkalemia should be anticipated with vigorous

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above are true statements.

questions.correct_answer: D. None of the above are true statements.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above are true statements. Metabolic acidosis can occur because of an increase in endogenous acid production or loss of bicarbonate, or accumulation of endogenous acids Salicylate consumption causes metabolic acidosis. Treatment: When received in ER, vigorous gastric lavage with isotonic saline should be initiated immediately. ( Option A is wrong ) Following it, patients should receive at least one round of activated charcoal via nasogastric tube (1 g/kg up to 50 g). IV NaHCO3 is administered in amounts adequate to alkalinize the urine ( urine pH > 7.5 ), to maintain urine output ( Option B is wrong ) Hypokalemia should be anticipated and treated ( Option C is wrong) Acetazolamide may be administered in the face of alkalemia, when Alkaline diuresis cannot be achieved, or To ameliorate volume overload associated with NaHCO3 administration.

Highyeild:

IV NaHCO3 can cause metabolic acidosis if the excreted HCO3 − is not replaced Hypoglycemia should be anticipated and treated.

Extraedge:

NaHCO3 facilitates the removal of salicylate because raising the urine pH from 6.5 to 7.5 increases salicylate clearance fivefold. Patients with coexisting respiratory alkalosis should also receive NaHCO3, but with caution to avoid excessive alkalemia

questions.text: A 39-year-old male weighing 60 kg is admitted to ICU and is found to have severe metabolic acidosis with ph 7 and HCO3 -9 meq/l. He is to be started on bicarbonate infusion. What is the total bicarbonate deficit in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

619 meq -Bicarbonate deficit is given by the formula Bicarbonate deficit = (24- HCO3) x( 0.4 +2.6 )x weight HCO3 = (24-9) x (0.4 +2.6/9)x 60 =15x 0.688x60 = 619 meq Therefore the total bicarbonate deficit is 619 meq 50% of this dose is to be infused in 4 hrs and rest gradually over 24 hrs Potential Indications for Bicarbonate Therapy in Metabolic Acidosis Indication Rationale Severe hypobicarbonatemia (<4 mEq/L) Insufficient buffer concentrations may lead to extreme increases in acidemia with small increases in acidosis. Severe acidemia (pH <7.00 to 7.15)" in cases of wide anion gap acidosis, with signs of shock or myocardial irritability that has not responded to supportive measures including adequate ventilation and fluid resuscitation as indicated by the patient's clinical characteristics Therapy for the underlying cause of acidosis depends on adequate organ perfusion Severe hyperchloremic acidemia Lost bicarbonate must be regenerated by the kidneys and liver, which may require days. "Presented as a range because recommendations differ among authors; data do not support a specific threshold for treatment. *No specific threshold indication by pH exists. The presence of serious hemodynamic insufficiency despite supportive care should guide the use of bicarbonate therapy for this indication. Source: Tintinallis Emergency Medicine A Comprehensive Study Guide 8th

questions.text: A 36-year-old male is being worked up for the cause of his secondary hypertension. He is found to have metabolic alkalosis. Further evaluation reveals High renin and high aldosterone levels. All the following are possible causes for his hypertension:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

11B hydroxylase deficiency This patient has metabolic alkalosis. To establish the cause of metabolic alkalosis, it is necessary to assess the Status of the ECFV Recumbent and upright blood pressure Serum [K] Urine [Cl] Renin-aldosterone system For patients of metabolic alkalosis with ECFV expansion , hypertension , K+ deficiency, and mineralocorticoid excess, the causes to be considered are: High renin Renal artery stenosis ( Option A ) Accelerated hypertension Renin-secreting tumor ( Option B ) Estrogen therapy Low renin Primary aldosteronism (Adenoma, Hyperplasia, Carcinoma) Adrenal enzyme defects (11β-Hydroxylase deficiency ( Option C ) 17α Hydroxylase deficiency) Cushing’s syndrome or disease ( Option D ) Others (Licorice, Carbenoxolone, Chewer’s tobacco) Option C is the answer here as it has low renin. (Not high)

Highyeild:

Symptoms of metabolic alkalosis with changes in CNS and peripheral nervous system function are similar to symptoms of hypocalcemia. Hypokalemia and hypophosphatemia are seen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male, a chronic alcoholic, presents to the casualty in an inebriated state. His last drink was 12 hours ago. He has had multiple episodes of vomiting and abdominal pain. He had initial blurring of vision but now it has progressed to complete loss of vision. In the emergency, he subsequently develops GTCS and is immediately shifted to the ICU.ABG done shows HAGMA. What is the possible agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methanol The patient is suffering from Methanol poisoning. Its metabolite formic acid is more toxic than methanol itself. Initially ethanol-like intoxication symptoms (Inebriated state): Nausea Vomiting Pain in abdomen Visual abnormalities (Clouding, spots, blindness) Seizures Coma CVS depression (in severe cases) Formic acid metabolite causes High AG metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) and retinal toxicity HAGMA, Increased osmolar gap, and increased osmolality are seen.

Highyeild:

High-dose folinic acid or folate facilitates the metabolism Ethanol or Fomepizole given in the presence of HAGMA Visual symptoms Methanol level >6 mmol/L (20 mg/dL) Symptoms of ethanol-like intoxication with increased osmolar gap Hemodialysis is indicated in Persistent HAGMA Lack of clinical improvement Renal dysfunction

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A - Cyanide presents with signs and symptoms of hypoxemia , and lactic acidosis with normal Pao2 but decreased SpaO2 . A bitter almond breath odor may be present. Option C - Opioid poisoning presents with muscarinic and nicotinic signs and symptoms like increased secretions , respiratory distress, and constricted pupil . There is no loss of vision as seen in this patient. Option D - Alcohol withdrawal will not have HAGMA, or symptoms pertaining to this patient like loss of vision.

Extraedge:

Hemodialysis enhances methanol elimination when methanol level is >15 mmol/L (50 mg/dL)

questions.text: A 38-year-old male is admitted with chief complaints of fever and abdominal pain for the last 2 days. His HR-110 bpm, BP-100/60mmHg RR-28 cpm. Ultrasound done shows features suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Preoperative investigations and ABG done are as follows. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HAGMA + NAGMA + respiratory alkalosis As per the ABG available in the Q pH - 7.28 Primary acidosis ( pH < 7.35) HCO3 - 7 Metabolic acidosis Respiratory compensation expected in a metabolic acidosis would be Paco2 = (1.5 × HCO3) + 8 ± 2 ( Winter’s equation ) Paco2 = (1.5 x 7) +8 ±2 = 18.5 ±2 mmHg. (In the patient it is much less than the compensated value – indicating a co-existing respiratory alkalosis) AG = Na - (Cl +HCO3) 135 - (106+7) = 22 meq/l → ( HAGMA ) Delta ratio = AG – 10 / 25 – HCO3 = 22 – 10 / 25 – 7 = 12 /18 = 0.66 (Mixed HAGMA + NAGMA ) So the patient has HAGMA + NAGMA + Respiratory alkalosis ( Option C )

Highyeild:

Delta ratio < 0.4 → NAGMA Delta ratio 0.4 - 0.8 → NAGMA+HAGMA Delta ratio 1 – 2 → HAGMA Delta ratio > 2 → HAGMA + metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: A 62-year-old male known case of bronchial asthma is admitted to the medicine ward with multiple episodes of diarrhea. His ABG and laboratory investigations are as follows.What is the underlying acid-base disorder in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HAGMA + NAGMA + Respiratory acidosis As per the ABG available in the Q pH - 7 Primary acidosis ( pH < 7.35) HCO3 - 4 Metabolic acidosis Respiratory compensation expected in a metabolic acidosis would be Paco2 = (1.5 × HCO3) + 8 ± 2 ( Winter’s equation ) Paco2 = (1.5 x 4) +8 ±2 = 14 ±2 mmHg (In the patient it is much higher than compensated value – indicating a co-existing respiratory acidosis. AG = Na - (Cl +HCO3) 135 - (104 + 4) = 27 meq/l → ( HAGMA ) Delta ratio = AG – 10 / 25 – HCO3 = 27 – 10 / 25 – 4 = 17 /21 = 0.8 (Mixed HAGMA + NAGMA ) So the patient has HAGMA + NAGMA + Respiratory acidosis ( Option C )

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & D. are not the correct metabolic abnormalities in this case.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a history of low-grade fever and easy fatigability. She also gives a history of dryness of eyes and mouth for the last 2-3 months. Her Laboratory investigations are shown below:

options.label: B
options.text: NAGMA due to Renal Tubular Acidosis

options.label: C
options.text: Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) due to GI loss

questions.correct_answer: B. NAGMA due to Renal Tubular Acidosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NAGMA due to Renal Tubular Acidosis As per the ABG available in the Q pH – 7.3 Primary acidosis ( pH < 7.35) HCO3 - 18 Metabolic acidosis Respiratory compensation expected in a metabolic acidosis would be Paco2 = (1.5 × HCO3) + 8 ± 2 ( Winter’s equation ) Paco2 = (1.5 x 18) +8 ±2 = 35 ±2 mmHg (In the patient it is c ompensated) AG = Na - (Cl + HCO3) 136 – (108+18) = 10 meq/l → ( NAGMA ) ( Option A is wrong ) To know the cause of Metabolic acidosis, Urinary AG should be measured . UAG = (Urine Na + urine K) –Urine Cl (20 + 12) – 12 = 20 ( Positive value ) If UAG is negative - Urine ammonium level is appropriately increased, suggesting an extra-renal cause of the acidosis. ( Option C is wrong ) If UAG is positive - Urine ammonium level is predictably low, suggesting a renal tubular origin of the acidosis. ( Option B is correct) The clinical scenario is likely of Sjogren’s syndrome along with RTA (NAGMA plus hypokalemia)

Highyeild:

Ideal method to measure urine ammonium is by adaptation of automated plasma ammonium assays, using the enzymatic method , if the urine sample is diluted 1:200 in normal saline.

questions.text: The following ABG is noted in an 8-year-old child who is brought to the emergency in an unresponsive state. pH-7.5 PCO2-80mmHg P02-95mmHg HCO3-48meq/l GRBS-102 mg/dl Na/K/Cl 140/3.5/92 Urine chloride- 10 meq/l All of the following can be a cause of his underlying acid-base disorder except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary Hyperaldosteronism As per the ABG available in the Q pH – 7.5} Primary alkalosis ( pH > 7.45) HCO3 - 48} Metabolic alkalosis Urine chloride is 10 meq (i.e < 20) → Chloride responsive alkalosis Causes of Chloride responsive alkalosis: Vomiting ( Option A is correct ) GI losses ( Option B is correct ) Chloride diarrhea Post hypercapnia Villous adenoma ( Option D is correct ) Diuretics Urine chloride > 20 meq → Chloride unresponsive alkalosis Chlorine unresponsive alkalosis with low renin → Primary aldosteronism ( Option C is wrong and that is the answer )
